citeinfo.title: Raw Ground Penetrating Radar Data, Eklutna Glacier, Alaska; 2013
citeinfo.geoform: Sensors and Software PulseEKKO (.HD,.DT1,.GPS) radargram files, PDF maps, excel spreadsheets, text files.

citeinfo.title: 2013 Raw Ground Penetrating Radar Data on Alaska's glaciers

descript.abstract: Common-offset GPR surveys were conducted with a Sensors and Software 500-MHz Pulse Ekko Pro system. We collected data from the ground, towed behind a researcher on skis or snowmobile, and from the air, strapped underneath a helicopter. All of the profiles are linked to coincident GPS observations. Coincident in-situ data is provided for calibration, and may be composed of any of the following: snow pits and/or snow-pit/snow-core combinations, probe profiles, and ablation stakes. This supplemental information may be used to calibrate velocity for conversion from time domain to depth domain. This supplemental information is provided as is, with additional information specific to usage included within the in-situ folder.
descript.purpose: Data were obtained to measure snow thickness on Alaska Glaciers for local and regional scale mass balance modeling.
descript.supplinf: Collection parameters varied within data set. Additional information regarding parameters and settings included with these data.

theme.themekey: Cryosphere > Glaciers/Ice Sheets > Ablation Zones/Accumulation Zones

idinfo.useconst: USGS/listed authors should be cited and given credit for the data. When appropriate, please consider co-authorship with the owners of the database. These data are the result of efforts by many of government and non-government participants in the field, as well as, USGS and various researchers and managers. All publications based on these data should acknowledge all of these efforts. If a publication is based solely on the analysis of this data, we suggest that you involve the authors of this data with the writing and/or review of the manuscript. We would also appreciate receiving a reprint or copy of any publications or reports that make use of the data.
idinfo.datacred: University of Alaska Fairbanks, Alaska Division of Geological & Geophysical Surveys, USGS Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.title: End-of-winter snow water equivalent variability on Alaskan glaciers

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted. All of the profiles are linked to coincident GPS observations. Coincident in-situ data is provided for calibration, and may be composed of any of the following: snow pits and/or snow-pit/snow-core combinations, probe profiles, and ablation stakes. This supplemental information may be used to calibrate velocity for conversion from time domain to depth domain. This supplemental information is provided as is, with additional information specific to usage included within the in-situ folder.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: These are raw unprocessed radargrams. Methods are described in McGrath et al 2015

procstep.procdesc: No process steps have been described for this data set

spdoinfo.indspref: Eastern Alaska Range, Delta Range, East of Richardson Highway north of Paxson, Phelan Creek drainage

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

overview.eaover:
.GPS files contain NMEA strings, see the following link for more information: http://www.gpsinformation.org/dale/nmea.htm
.HD files contain header information, see sensors and software manual (http://www.sensoft.ca/ or http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/~geology/jiracek/sage/documents/Sensors%20and%20Software%20GPR%20Manual.pdf),
.DT1 files contain trace data in binary format, which cannot be opened with a text editor. Can be read into matlab, see sensors and software manual listed above for file structure.
overview.eadetcit: Annan AP and Sensors & Software Inc. (1993) Practical Processing of GPR Data. Proceedings of the Second Government Workshop on Ground Penetrating Radar. Columbus, Ohio http://www.ees.nmt.edu/outside/courses/Geop446/Docs/GPR_data_process.pdf

distinfo.distliab:
Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The USGS or the U.S. Government shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
USGS/listed authors should be cited and given credit for the data. When appropriate, please consider co-authorship with the owners of the database. These data are the result of efforts by many of government and non-government participants in the field, as well as, USGS and various researchers and managers. All publications based on these data should acknowledge all of these efforts. If a publication is based solely on the analysis of this data, we suggest that you involve the authors of this data with the writing and/or review of the manuscript. We would also appreciate receiving a reprint or copy of any publications or reports that make use of the data.

digtinfo.formcont: This WinZip file contains data directories with raw GPR data as well as the associated metadata files.

distinfo.techpreq: This zip file contains data in sensors and software pulseEKKO format. The user must have software capable of un-compressing the WinZip file and reading .DT1 data(for example, http://www.sandmeier-geo.de/GPR.html or http://www.sensoft.ca/) . Additionally, spreadsheets in .xls format, and maps in .pdf format are provided. If unable to download data, contact Shad O'Neel (soneel@usgs.gov) to access the data by other means.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
